To have been able to secure this opportunity on these terms is testament to the MX Oil management's ability to source and secure interests in assets with company-making potential. We are looking forward to announcing a spud date for our Aje production well in the near term, and are excited by the prospect of bringing this field into production with our new partners and beginning to realise Aje's excellent potential. Alongside expected production by January 2016, the next six months promise a great deal of newsflow which should excite our shareholders, as we look to create a leading oil and gas company."

Each important reform must be designed either to accommodate or boost a rapid increase in household income or wealth or it must be structured to pay down debt… it is important to understand that wealth transfers are fully compatible with supply-side reforms, depending on how the reforms are formulated.”

undefined
BE

So, Lloyds requested.

Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 64.47, down 2.39 (-3.57%), High: 66.73, Low: 64.47, Volume: 56.03m
11:16 am
BE

I think this is on the back of a Cazenove note talking about NIM pressure

BE

Though it's one of those "buy on lower estimates" pieces.

BE

Despite revenue pressure from a lower for longer UK rate environment, we
believe that Lloyds is best positioned within the sector to complete its balance
sheet transformation and become a dividend growth story. At its FY15 results
on 25th Feb, we expect Lloyds to announce a DPS of 2.0p (incl. a 0.5p special
divi). We expect increasing focus on its capital return potential post FY15
results and expect cumulative 18p DPS over the period 4Q15-2018E (27% of
mkt cap) while CET1 increases from 13.7% to 16.0%. Lloyds has
outperformed SX7P by 8% over the last 1 year and at 8.0x P/E, 8.2% total div
yield for 2017E and with 34% potential upside to our 90p PT, we view any
pull back as a buying opportunity. Lloyds remains our top UK bank pick.

11:17 am
BE

Shift in UK regulatory stance helpful for capital return, in our view:
The BOE has confirmed that the i) UK system broadly has the right amount
of capital, with any future regulatory changes likely to result in a
reallocation within the system rather than a rise in absolute capital levels;
and ii) a non-zero CCyB is already factored into current CT1 requirements.

BE

NIM under pressure but multiple offsets available for Lloyds: With UK
interest rate increase expectations being delayed, we cut our NIM forecast
for Lloyds and believe that NIM could decline further in 2016 in the
absence of rate hikes which we build in our model. However, we expect the
NIM trajectory at Lloyds to outperform that of the other UK banks due to:
o NIM accretive growth strategy: i) slower growth in mortgages (+1%
y/y); ii) strong growth in UK consumer finance (+17% y/y) & SME (+5%
y/y); and iii) noncore runoff (£15bn).
o Potential ECN buyback: We estimate that ECN redemption will benefit
Lloyds’ NIM by 3-7bps and adj. EPS by 2-4% depending on the
instrument replacing the ECNs. We have not built in the ECN benefit in
our estimates and this could provide upside to our forecasts.
o Opportunity on liability repricing: Lloyds paid 115bps on its deposits in
2014 compared to 52bps at RBS & 25bps at Barclays. Over time, we
expect Lloyds to reprice the deposits to offset the asset margin pressure.

BE

Changes to ests: We cut our adj. EPS ests. by 2-3% driven by i) delay in
interest rate increase expectations, ii) impact of floods in insurance biz., iii)
lower loan growth assumptions; partly offset by iv) better costs & v) lower
impairments. We cut our Dec-16 PT to 90p driven by lower EPS / CT1 ratio.

Avi Vermus, Chief Executive of Digitek and PeerTV
Joined Digitek in 2011 as Chief Financial Officer and was appointed CEO in January 2012. Between 2009 and 2010 he was Chief Financial Officer at Teliran Ltd which is a circuit assembly factory serving the military and civilian sectors in Israel. From 2007 to 2008 he was CFO at Magnetico Ltd where his duties included control of a manufacturing facility in China. Between 2003 and 2007 he served as CFO at Compwise Ltd a software development and marketing company for revenue assurance. Previously he was Financial Manager at Derech Eretz, a construction company that built and operates the first major toll road in Israel. Mr Vermus is a Certified Public Accountant (Israel) and holds a BA in Accounting and Economics from Hebrew University, Jerusalem.

PM

Let me try and summarise briefly

PM

PM

Done

11:29 am
PM

Actually I will share their "portfolio manager's summary"

PM

For time pressured asset managers

PM

We have now enjoyed one of the longest economic expansions in history. Global car sales
in 2015 reached 87 million units (up 35% on 2009 levels) and the main OEMs will report
total EBIT of over US$130 billion — both all-time record highs. Perhaps global industry
earnings can hold up in 2016, but thereafter, we believe a decline is inevitable. We are at
the end of an era of super-normal Chinese pricing, global capacity shortages, cheap
money, and at the end of an era that has seen conventional vehicle technology still prevail.

11:29 am
PM

The most important factor behind the extraordinary growth in industry returns has been
the China boom. Many OEMs have enjoyed margins of over 20% in China — far above
global norms. But Chinese profitability has clearly begun to fall. The second key factor has
been the strong growth in U.S. market profitability in recent years. The U.S. government's
response to the GFC was highly effective and allowed the industry to "reboot," lowering
costs and lifting pricing. But volumes have now recovered, financing has been pushed to
the limit, new capacity is coming on stream, and there are early signs of deteriorating
pricing. With Chinese and U.S. profits set to roll over, it is hard to see what can provide an
offset. Almost all other emerging markets — many of them previously handsomely
profitable — have deteriorated. Europe is a bright spot, but since capacity was not
addressed in the crisis and the vehicle mix remains biased toward small cars, contribution
margins remain dismal.

PM

On top of negligible global volume growth, the industry is also about to face multiple new
challenges from tough emissions standards, diversifying powertrain options, connectivity,
autonomous driving, and perhaps even new industry entrants. Things are about to get
much more complex — both technologically and strategically. But that means it's going to
become a lot harder for OEMs and investors to make money. Do we have the right
expertise and skills to deal with this new era? We're not convinced. Investors used to want
us to analyze capacity, pricing, and costs. Now, everyone just wants to talk about
Apple iCar, Uber, and the sharing economy. It's all very interesting, but it doesn't
necessarily lend itself to financial analysis.

PM

We recommend a cautious stance on the sector. Stocks look fairly cheap on earnings
multiples, but that's because at some point soon, industry earnings will begin to roll over.
There will be very few OEMs that can out-run these conditions and make money for
investors. We will look back on the last few years as a true "golden era" for industry
profitability, and possibly for auto sector analysts.

Today, we have a rejig of the plan it seems to have been failing to deliver for about a decade.

BE

BE

BE

Anyway, here's Barclays.

11:42 am
BE

We consider the plan ambitious. While the 3 pillars of the strategy are clear and, in theory, within the company’s control, the level of profit delivery by Year 5 is reasonably ambitious. It does not provide details of how much price reinvestment will be necessary in the process, especially given competition intensifying in the UK with the potential entry of Bunnings, which bought Homebase. Year 5 profit uplift of £500m would potentially mean a c20% upgrade to Bloomberg consensus PBT and may excite the imagination of long-term holders assuming execution risks can be maintained. At the same time the P&L impact in Years 1 and 2 is larger than what we would have thought, implying a high single/ low double digit negative impact vs. FY17 and FY18 Bloomberg consensus PBT. The good operational track record of the current CEO will likely act as an advantage in the deliverance of this ambitious plan but today’s announced near-term profitability impacts will likely have a detrimental effect on the share price.

BE

Kingfisher will be targeting the delivery of £500m of extra profit by year 5 over and above “business as usual” and a capital return program of £600m share buybacks in the next three years. In the process KGF expects negative pre exceptional profit impact net of operational efficiency of -£50m in Year 1 (-7% vs Bbg FY17 PBT consensus) and -£70-100m in Year 2 (midpoint is -11% vs Bbg FY18 PBT consensus). Total cash costs for the implementation of the program will be £800m, i.e. 10% of current market cap (P&L costs £220m, exceptional costs £270m and capex of £310m).

Profit improvements are to come from 3 pillars:

1. Unified offer (+£350m profit by Year 5 and £480m cash costs) assuming 5% reduction in COGS and higher sales from price reinvestment

2. Digital capability improvement (+£50m by Year 5, cash cost £210m)

3. Optimising operational efficiency (+£100m profit by Year 5 and £110m cash costs) by unifying c.90% of £1.2bn goods not for resale.

BE

Honestly. It's Groundhog Day. Every bloody Kingfisher statement says "unified, digital, optimise" ....

11:43 am
BE

All that changes are the costs of delivery and the time, which pushes ever further towards the horizon.

BE

I mean seriously, they sell rawlplugs and shower fittings. Why's this proving so difficult?

PM

hehehehe

11:44 am
BE

In terms of competition from Oz, Barclays again.

BE

Homebase's acquisition by Wesfarmers and the subsequent rebranding to Bunnings will be another factor Kingfisher management will have to address and will potentially add to the existing pressure on sales and profitability. Bunnings announced to its investors that it is ready to invest £500m in the UK focusing on price, service and range, which will likely add to Kingfisher’s competitive pressure in the UK.

Bunnings’ slogan for the UK “Everything you want under one roof” (as per the company’s presentation in Australia to its investors) may be optimistic given the polarisation we observe in the UK consumer towards “Do it for me” big projects and spontaneous purchases on soft furnishings and decoration. We cannot overlook though that the operational and acquisitional track record of the company is impressive (only one year of EBIT decline in the past 20 years) and the brand value strong (Australia’s most trusted brand for 10 years). Bunnings has managed to achieve double-digit EBIT margins, above 30% ROCE while its scale with sales of c£4.5bn is not negligible, with Homebase adding another £1.5bn to this. It may well be that Bunnings underappreciates competition in the UK and its £500m announced investment could eventually hurt margins of the entire DIY industry. In any case though there is increased possibility that B&Q will have to respond with lower prices, more capex and increased staff expenses to fight back a more determined competitor than Homebase appeared to be. Increasing sales densities with intensifying competition in the UK may be tougher to achieve.

BE

(Acrobat's just crashed. One moment.)

11:45 am
BE

Just for balance, here's a buyer. UBS.

BE

Big benefits, but some costs as well
KGF has announced a 5-year transformation plan to deliver £500m sustainable profit
uplift by end of year 5, and over and above "business as usual". £350m will be from
c5% savings on cost of goods sold (COGS), £50m from e-commerce investment, and
£100m from operational savings (including Goods Not For Resale). However, there will
be costs attached - £220m through the P&L with a bias to early years (including
clearance costs), £270m of exceptional costs and £310m of transformational capex.
With management describing KGF as a "limited expansion" business, there will also be
a £600m capital return over the next three years.

BE

Sustainability the priority, in more ways than one
KGF is focusing on a sustainable profit uplift and the £500m profit improvement is
from both supply chain savings and the sales uplift from selective price reinvestment.
This seems sensible given occasions in the past when certain KGF businesses have been
out of line on price, and given the likely entry of Bunnings (Australia's leading DIY
retailer with sales of c£5bn, EBIT margin 11.4%) into the UK market. As well as seeking
to grow share of the target market of currently £38bn, there is a risk that Bunnings will
work off a lower gross margin.
Estimates likely to fall in early years, and rise thereafter
KGF guides that PX PBT will be impacted by c£50m in FY17 and £70-100m in FY18, net
of operational efficiency benefits. This would be c7% and c9% impact respectively,
although there could be a partial offset from the recent strengthening of the euro.
Further out, the costs will drop away and the benefits will accelerate and estimates
should start to rise sharply.
Valuation: Buy, Price Target 400p
KGF trades on c14x cal16E PE, broadly in line with peers. Our PT is set under DCF and
takes explicit five-year estimates, a fade to terminal sales growth and EBIT margin of
2.5% and 7% (FY16E 6.7%) and WACC of 8.5%.

11:46 am
undefined
PM

You know we are going to be flooded with Brexit stuff for the forseeable

PM

When is it likely ? the referendum

11:47 am
PM

Credit Suisse say June

PM

The EU referendum is the key risk event facing the UK in 2016. Our base-case scenario is that the referendum will be held in June 2016 and the UK will vote to stay in the European Union.
· The increased uncertainty around the referendum is likely to cause financial and economic volatility and negatively impact growth in the short term. Consequently, the timing and path of rate hikes may also get affected. However the impact is expected to be relatively muted if the UK votes to stay.
· If the UK votes to leave the EU, it is likely to entail an immediate and simultaneous economic and financial shock for the UK. We can expect a drop in business investment, hiring and confidence. A sudden stop of capital flowing into the UK could make the large current account deficit difficult to sustain and lead to a sharp fall in sterling. In its most extreme that could mean a level drop in GDP of 1%-2% in the short term due to the toxic blend of depressed business confidence, tightening financial conditions, higher inflation and falling real incomes. In the medium term, we expect it to be negative for UK demand and supply, implying a weaker GDP growth path.

PM

FX Strategy: Our FX forecasts should be seen as a probability-weighted expected move using roughly a 60:40 probability of staying in/leaving the EU. If the UK were to vote to leave, we would expect EURGBP to push on towards 0.83, its average level since 2009. This leaves room for GBPUSD to trade towards 1.20 if EURUSD pushes lower towards parity as we expect. Conversely, if Brexit is rejected, we would expect EURGBP to be around 0.70 in 12 months’ time, with GBPUSD well above 1.40.
· Rates Strategy: We believe it makes sense to be long gilts on cross-market basis and we favour GBP 10s30s steepeners into the referendum. Should the UK vote to leave, we expect a bull steepening of GBP 2s10s.
· ABS Strategy: We expect (i) structurally wider spreads, with the RMBS market underperforming both government and covered bonds, (ii) foreign-currency issuance to dry up. For investors concerned about the outcome, it makes sense to either reduce risk early, or to hedge via other, more liquid asset classes, that are likely to reprice sooner.
· Equity Strategy: We continue to recommend buying UK-listed euro earners; remain cautious of UK domestic cyclicals (especially UK office REITs and London-focused housebuilders); be long the FTSE 100 versus FTSE 250, and we highlight a group of stocks we think could be negatively impacted. From a regional allocation perspective, we have not changed our benchmark recommendation on UK equities: with only 21% of earnings from the UK, weaker sterling would, we think, offset the higher discount rate placed on UK-related earning streams.

11:56 am
undefined
PM

Leggie wants a bit on Petra

PM

e's Shore as well

11:56 am
PM

Short Shore]

PM

FY2016 target of 3.3-3.4Mct; but revenues 28% down on H1 FY2015 on weaker prices (and lower sales). Q2 FY2016 production fell slightly, resulting in H1 FY2016 production of 1.63Mct – but this was still ahead of guidance of 1.5Mct and H1 FY2015’s 1.60Mct. Reasonably, in our view, Petra therefore believes it is on-track to achieve its full-year FY2016 target of 3.3-3.4Mct for FY2016 and c.5Mct by FY2019.

Petra had previously cautioned that volatility in the rough diamond market meant that there could be “deviations” from its guidance of flat diamond pricing in FY2016. The company today revealed that rough prices in H1 FY2015 were c.9% down on Q4 FY2015 like-for-like, offset somewhat by an improving product mix.

H1 FY2016 revenue was nonetheless down significantly (28%) at US$154m (H1 FY2015: US$214.8m) - albeit partially due to lower sales of 1.3Mct (H1 FY2015: 1.4Mct). As in previous years, Petra is expecting H2 to be stronger for sales due to tender timings, with sales volume this year expected to be 1.9-2.0Mct. Lower dollar prices are also being offset by the significant weakening of the South African rand.

As of end H1 FY2016, net debt was US$324.4m (H2 FY2015: US$171.7m) while cash had decreased to US$41.6m (H2 FY2015: US$166.6m). Undrawn, available debt facilities totalled US$177.1m (H2 FY2015: US$255.1m).

Petra Diamonds Ltd (PDL:LSE): Last: 71.75, up 0.25 (+0.35%), High: 76.75, Low: 70.50, Volume: 1.20m
11:57 am
PM

And a Panmure snap

PM

Petra's Q2 FY2016 production and sales report provided no major surprises. As expected, production continued to improve but revenues fell, impacted by the weakness in diamond pricing during the second half of 2015 and the decision to hold two tenders instead of the normal three in the period. Commentary for diamond pricing remains optimistic and in line with our recent sector note, the "Quarterly Carat X". Despite the declines in diamond prices, Petra continues to enjoy operational benefits from the weaker South African Rand. We reiterate our Buy recommendation and 112p price target, based on a blended average of NAV/Share and EPS

PM

Buyers

11:57 am
PM

Kieron Hodgson

PM

And Spangel are looking for 156p

PM

Conclusion: Operationally these numbers look good with Cullinan and Koffiefontein performing showing better performance in Q2 2015 in terms of grades. At Finsch tailings performed better than ROM tonnages. Key will be pricing to be achieved in the tenders to be held in the second half – Petra appears to be saying the market and pricing will be flat from here – our revenue numbers in the second half still need to reflect this.

Revenues and carats sold for the first half in line with expectations and two tenders already announced of US$154m including exceptional stone sale from Williamson of US$10m.
Diamonds sold for the first half down 7% on the same time last year at 1.303m carats,
Production for the first half of 1.629m carats in line with guidance for the full year of 3.3-3.4m carats and up 2% on the same time last year.
Finsch ROM slightly below at the halve way point with tailings performing well.
Improved grades coming through at Cullinan and Koffiefontein on ROM production with grade improvement of 9% and 13% respectively.
Diamond production improved at Cullinan by 18% to 322,366 carats and at Koffiefontein by 61% to 31,760 carats as ramp up seen in the new SLC production.
Diamond inventories at US$57.4m against US$43.6m with the typical cycle of 4 tenders in the second half expected to the first half.
Petra expects a stable market for diamond sales in the second half of FY 2016 with an improvement coming through in FY 2017 (second half of calendar 2016).
Rough diamond prices are down 9% for H1 2016 as previously announced with the fall in the rand helping to cushion price falls.
The rand has fallen by 26% in H1 2016.
Expansion capex spend in line with Cullinan project progressing well and in line with expectations.
Net debt at US$152.7m with cash at the end of the period of US$41.6m.
Undrawn bank facilities stood at US$177.1m.

12:00 pm
BE

H1 has been impacted by restructuring and delayed mega-projects as well as
increased investment to expand in Asia/India/Middle East. We re-initiate with
reduced forecasts and a Price Target of 55p. The company has what we believe
is an exceptionally strong business model, which will eventually carry the day.
 Trading Update (6mths to Dec): Consolidation period. Earthport expects H1 revenues
to be “in excess of £10.5m” for stated organic growth of 18% YoY and 4% HoH.
Revenues have been impacted by an undisclosed amount by de-emphasising some
areas. Underlying revenue growth might have been c. 25% YoY and c.10% HoH ex this.
Gross margins are expected to be some 75%, which is consistent with levels seen over
FY13 and FY14 after a record FY15.
 Medium and long term prospects “very significant”. Earthport believes that market
acceptance with existing clients is accelerating, and now also in Asia and Middle East,
where the company is investing to expand.
 Forecast changes. We reduce FY16 revenues from £30m to £23m, and FY17 from
£48m to £31m. We introduce FY18 at £43m. We reduce FY16 adj. PBTA from -£0.5)m
to £(6.5)m and FY17 from £10m to £(3)m. We introduce FY18 PBTA of £6m.
 The opportunity remains and the business model is fit for purpose. Mega projects
remain in the pipeline for core customers such as BoA (which we assess in some detail
in a report we are publishing today). Having paid fines of c.$80bn since 2009, IT
budgets are returning to banks such as BoA. Earthport has an exceptional business
model. Strong organic growth is coupled with a high degree of repeat/transactional
revenues (85%). GM of 75% offers significant and proven operational leverage. The
accounts are clean and the balance sheet strong. We make an assessment of this
model in this report noting that revs/employee of $170k should more than double.
 Our target model sees margins of c.30% on of sales of £70m at some point. When is
difficult to predict, but if Earthport achieves the above target model it should be
throwing off FCF of c.£15m p.a. We re-initiate at Buy. Price Target 55p.

BE

Kevin Ashton's the analyst.
